data.title: Zurn Elkay Water Solutions Doubled My Money, But I'm Downgrading Anyway
data.description:
Thesis

A couple of years ago, I started covering Zurn Elkay Water Solutions (ZWS), a Milwaukee-based company that designs and makes plumbing and water management systems for commercial, institutional, and industrial buildings. I rated the stock a Buy back then. I like companies like ZWS. They’re straightforward, easy to follow, and kind of old-school in this fast-paced AI era. At the time, I thought the company’s stock price was in a good spot compared to its long-term potential, thanks to rising demand for clean water infrastructure and the early benefits of the Zurn–Elkay merger.

Since my call, ZWS has been one of the best movers in my portfolio, and hopefully yours too, gaining about 135% compared to roughly 66% for the S&P 500 (SP500). But after such a big run, it’s fair to ask whether ZWS still has more room to grow.

After looking at the latest Q3 results, my research suggests that Zurn Elkay’s strong fundamentals, including wider profit margins, solid cash flow, and policy-driven demand for safe water infrastructure, point to a sustainable growth story. However, the company’s stock price now already reflects much of that strength and success.

Zurn Elkay’s Q3 Highlights: Growth, Margins, and Momentum

By and large this quarter, it looked like Zurn Elkay did well in the areas it could directly manage and held steady where the market just wouldn’t budge, as the overall business climate was slow and steady.

In that setting, the results come in with revenue reported at $455 million, that's up 11% from last year, with core growth also at 11%.

EPS was $0.43, about three cents higher than expected. Adjusted EBITDA rose 16% to $122 million. Meanwhile, the profit margin widened by 120 basis points to 26.8%, the highest quarterly margin since the Elkay merger.

On the call, management said the results came from higher volume and the steady daily grind of the Zurn Elkay Business System. Pricing added about five percentage points, and unit volumes grew too, which is a good tell that indicates that real demand is present and not just higher prices that's driving these results. At the same time, about $8 million in customer orders were moved up into September ahead of a planned price increase. Even so, management said their guidance assumes that timing will balance out in the fourth quarter, not artificially boost the growth rate.

Nonresidential business stayed strong, while residential stayed weak. That might sound typical, but you have to keep in mind that Zurn Elkay has a bigger presence in education, health care, and public spaces, and these are areas where drinking water solutions are now seen as required items. In other words, state rules are turning into real purchase orders, which drives steady demand in those segments.

Take Michigan’s Filter First law. It set aside $50 million for schools and child care centers, with hard deadlines to finish the job. A statewide grant program has also been established in the state of New Jersey, which establishes precise timetables for guidance, bidding, and installation. Operationally, the point is that these programs build deadline-driven, budgeted demand that isn’t tied to new construction, and naturally, they're going to favor those suppliers already certified and on site.

The company’s profits and cash generation seemed to be the main drivers this quarter. Free cash flow came in at $94 million. So far this year, sales have increased by $93 million, and EBITDA has gone up by $39 million, meaning about 42% of the extra sales turned into profit. The year-to-date EBITDA margin is also up by 1.2 percentage points, on top of 8% core growth, and that's exactly the kind of improvement I want to see when overall market demand isn’t providing much help.

Net leverage dropped to just 0.6x, the lowest level since the company went public, which buys optionality. During the quarter, the company bought back $25 million worth of its own stock, bringing the year-to-date total to $135 million, which equals about 3.8% of all shares.

It also raised its dividend by 22% (see FAST Graphs data above) and renewed its stock buyback program, authorizing up to $500 million more. Essentially, by shutting down its U.S. pension plan and shedding roughly $200 million in liabilities, the company simplified its balance sheet and made future management easier.

Zurn Elkay: Pricing Discipline and Regulatory Fit

Having noted that, costs have gone up. Back in August, new rules added a 50% tariff on some partly processed copper imports. And because of that, management now expects to pay around $50 million in tariffs; that's higher than their earlier estimate of around $35–45 million. Despite that, the company acted early to offset this. It raised list prices in April, which affected the entire next quarter, and made another adjustment in mid-September to update rates for each country and for copper materials.

On the call, the CFO explained that the price benefit should show up in the first half of next year, which will help revenues during those quarters. Keep in mind, those price increases don’t boost results overnight; it takes a bit for them to fully flow through the numbers, so the first half of 2026 will likely look stronger as the effects of those higher prices continue to show up. By the second half of 2026, that effect will fade. After a full year of higher prices, it just becomes the new normal.

Nevertheless, let's go back to the regulation environment since the company's product features and government rules worked together in a good way. If you aren't aware, schools and districts require filters that meet NSF/ANSI Standard 53 for removing lead and Standard 42 for improving taste and removing particles. In certain cases, some bid lists also ask for Standards 372 and 401, which deal with low lead content and microplastic removal. Elkay’s main bottle fillers and filters already meet all these standards. My read, which is grounded in the numbers we just went over, is that once customers standardize on Zurn Elkay’s systems, they tend to stay there. Therefore, when new funding shows up, the buying happens fast—no long comparison shopping, just orders.

Elkay Pro Filtration gained early success because its filters are quicker to install and last longer. I'd argue that that could be a big help for maintenance teams already stretched thin while trying to meet safety rules across many locations. Liv EZ, the new built-in water bottle filler for homes, is a smaller side project. The company isn’t depending on home sales for growth, but this product brings Elkay’s strong commercial-grade filtration into homes, where people already know and trust the brand from places like schools and offices.

Balanced Outlook for 2025

Moving on to the company’s outlook, it does strike a balance between optimism and caution. In the first nine months, order rates were just slightly higher than shipments, and management expects the fourth quarter to be about even, meaning they plan to produce only what customers actually need, not oversupply distributors. As for the fourth quarter, the company's projecting core sales growth in the high single digits and adjusted earnings (EBITDA) between $99 million and $102 million.

For the full year, the company expects about 8% growth in core sales, EBITDA between $437 million and $440 million, and more than $300 million in free cash flow. The overall message seems to fit the broader economy; that is, commercial construction isn’t booming, and financing remains tight, but I'd say that the company’s own growth drivers are strong enough to keep business steadily building even without a surge in new projects.

Zurn Elkay’s Valuation

At the current share price, ZWS is trading at a P/E ratio of 33.6, and even looking ahead, the forward P/E is 31.5.

That’s quite a bit higher than the typical industrial company’s 21 and even above its own five-year average of around 28.

The same pattern shows up in other measures too, with the EV-to-EBITDA ratio at 18.4, compared with about 12.7 for the sector; the EV-to-sales ratio is 4.78 versus 2.18, and the forward price-to-cash-flow is 24.8, while peers sit near 16.4.

The dividend yield is under 1%, so income investors won’t get much comfort there. That is to say, from that angle, the market seems happy to pay a steep price for what it sees as quality, stability, and government-supported growth, and then tack on an extra layer of optimism for good management.

FAST Graphs throws on some more cold water. Its model says the fair value is around $21.43, which is less than half the current price, and it even shows a potential annual loss of about 22.5% if the stock drifts back to a more “normal” P/E ratio of 26.4.

Analysts’ forecasts help ease some of that risk, but they don’t make it go away. EPS is anticipated to increase by 14.6% in 2025, then drop down to 9.4% in 2026 and 8.4% in 2027, before rising up again to 18.5% in 2028, according to Wall Street's projections. If that plays out, how much investors make overall will depend more on where that P/E ratio ends up than on the actual growth in earnings.

Final Takeaway

After a strong run the past couple of years, I’m moving ZWS to a Hold. Despite the fact that the company's performance and long-term prognosis are strong, the premium price of the stock already bakes in a significant portion of the company's strength. It could still be a good buy if earnings pick up or state-funded filtration demand grows faster than expected.

data.title: Thornburg Core Plus Bond Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Despite volatility, our focus continues to be on generating attractive income and risk-adjusted total returns over the long term.

Market Review

Markets showed resilience despite effective tariff rates increasing sevenfold since the beginning of the year, while the current administration announced several new protectionist measures including 100% tariffs on foreign-made movies, substantial tariffs on imported furniture, and potential requirements for semiconductor manufacturers to match foreign production with domestic output. Trade uncertainty was partially mitigated by reciprocal tariff arrangements, a 90-day postponement on China tariffs, and bilateral deals. The Federal Reserve began its rate cutting cycle with a 25 basis point reduction in September, with updated projections indicating an additional 50 basis points of cuts expected before year end. Concerns about Fed independence surfaced when the administration announced plans to fire Fed Governor Cook over alleged mortgage fraud.

Treasury yields fluctuated throughout the period, with short-end yields declining approximately 30-40 basis points as rate-cut expectations increased. The curve steepened with the 30-year yield falling 7 basis points since the start of the quarter. Despite weakening labor market indicators, including the narrowest labor market differential since early 2021 in the September Consumer Confidence survey, economic data remained positive, supporting narratives of consumer resilience, improved trade clarity, and stronger corporate capital expenditure. As the quarter ended, the federal government faced an imminent shutdown with no funding deal reached by September 30.

Third Quarter 2025 Performance Highlights

  • In 3Q25 the portfolio (I share class) returned 2.34%, 31 basis points ahead of the Bloomberg U.S. Universal Index. Year to date the portfolio (I share class) returned 6.57%, 44 basis points ahead of the index.
  • Sector allocation and security selection contributed positively to relative outperformance with the portfolio’s treasury underweight and security selection within corporate bonds providing uplift of 11 and 6 basis points, respectively. Specifically, the portfolio’s security selection within corporates and CMO’s resulted in strong contributions to relative performance.
  • The portfolio maintained an average duration of 6.27 versus 6.03 for the index with the overweight duration and yield curve positioning contributing 4 basis points from relative performance for the quarter. Rates across the board fell in Q3 and the curve continued to steepen with short-end rates falling 30-40 basis points and the long end falling 8-10 basis points.

Current Positioning and Outlook

The strategy remained positioned with a longer duration and higher quality bias compared to its long-term range, driven by attractive real yields and tight credit spreads. Security selection, driven by our bottom-up fundamental credit research, was a key contributor, allowing us to identify resilient issuers across various sectors and industries. Corporate credit spreads tightened significantly, approaching levels not seen since the 1990s, and we remain cautious on adding incremental credit risk as the compensation for doing so remains near historic lows. Real yields remain attractive relative to history, compensating investors for fiscal largesse, government dysfunction (shutdowns), and persistent inflation. While nimbleness around duration positioning remains important, interest rate volatility has been trending lower, perhaps suppressed by reduced government data flow.

We maintained broad diversification across fixed-income sectors with an emphasis on sectors demonstrating resilience or offering compelling risk/reward profiles identified through our research. The allocations to investment grade corporate credit and mortgage pass- throughs were large drivers of absolute returns during the period, however falling yields led to Treasuries outperforming.

Looking ahead, the global economy has shown surprising resilience despite mounting pressures from the delayed impact of tariffs and constrained fiscal flexibility. Additionally, the Fed must balance relatively persistent inflation with downside risks to the labor market alongside uncertainty surrounding the independence of the country’s institutions. With flexible mandates across many of our fixed income strategies—enabling us to dynamically adjust duration, credit exposure, and sector allocation—we remain positioned to take advantage of potential bouts of heightened volatility.

Class I shares may not be available to all investors. Minimum investments for the I share class may be higher than those for other classes.

Performance data shown represents past performance and is no guarantee of future results. Investment return and principal value will fluctuate so shares, when redeemed, may be worth more or less than their original cost. Current performance may be lower or higher than quoted. For performance current to the most recent month end, visit thornburg.com or call 877-215-1330. The maximum sales charge for the Fund's A shares is 4.50%. There is no up-front sales charge for class I shares. Thornburg Investment Management and/or Thornburg Securities LLC have contractually agreed to waive fees and reimburse expenses through at least 1 February 2026, for some of the share classes; these are reflected in the net expense ratio. For more detailed information on fund expenses and waivers/reimbursements, please see the fund's prospectus.

Portfolio Managers

Lon Erickson, CFA, Portfolio Manager

Christian Hoffmann, CFA, Head of Fixed Income

Supported by the entire Thornburg investment team

Performance data shown represents past performance and is no guarantee of future results. Investment return and principal value will fluctuate so shares, when redeemed, may be worth more or less than their original cost. Current performance may be lower or higher than quoted. For performance current to the most recent month end, visit thornburg.com or call 877-215-1330. There is no up-front sales charge for class I shares.

Important Information

Unless otherwise noted, the source of all data, charts, tables and graphs is Thornburg Investment Management, Inc., as of 30 September 2025.

The views expressed are subject to change and do not necessarily reflect the views of Thornburg Investment Management, Inc. This information should not be relied upon as a recommendation or investment advice and is not intended to predict the performance of any investment or market.

Investments carry risks, including possible loss of principal. Portfolios investing in bonds have the same interest rate, inflation, and credit risks that are associated with the underlying bonds. The value of bonds will fluctuate relative to changes in interest rates, decreasing when interest rates rise. This effect is more pronounced for longer-term bonds. Unlike bonds, bond funds have ongoing fees and expenses. Investments in lower rated and unrated bonds may be more sensitive to default, downgrades, and market volatility; these investments may also be less liquid than higher rated bonds. Investments in derivatives are subject to the risks associated with the securities or other assets underlying the pool of securities, including illiquidity and difficulty in valuation. Investments in equity securities are subject to additional risks, such as greater market fluctuations. Additional risks may be associated with investments outside the United States, especially in emerging markets, including currency fluctuations, illiquidity, volatility, and political and economic risks. Investments in the Fund are not FDIC insured, nor are they bank deposits or guaranteed by a bank or any other entity.

There is no guarantee that the Fund will meet its investment objectives.

Basis Point (BP) – A unit equal to 1/100th of 1%. 1% = 100 basis points (bps).

U.S. Treasury securities, such as bills, notes and bonds, are negotiable debt obligations of the U.S. government. These debt obligations are backed by the "full faith and credit" of the government and issued at various schedules and maturities. Income from Treasury securities is exempt from state and local, but not federal, taxes.

A bond credit rating assesses the financial ability of a debt issuer to make timely payments of principal and interest. Ratings of AAA (the highest), AA, A, and BBB are investment-grade quality. Ratings of BB, B, CCC, CC, C and D (the lowest) are considered below investment grade, speculative grade, or junk bonds.

Credit Spread/Quality Spread - The difference between the yields of securities with different credit qualities.

Duration - A bond's sensitivity to interest rates. Bonds with longer durations experience greater price volatility than bonds with shorter durations. Yield Curve - A line that plots the interest rates, at a set point in time, of bonds having equal credit quality, but differing maturity dates.

Asset-backed Security (ABS) - A security whose value and income payments are derived from and collateralized (or "backed") by a specified pool of underlying assets. The pool of assets is typically a group of small and illiquid assets that are unable to be sold individually. Pooling the assets into financial instruments allows them to be sold to general investors, a process called securitization, and allows the risk of investing in the underlying assets to be diversified because each security will represent a fraction of the total value of the diverse pool of underlying assets.

Mortgage Pass-Through - A security consisting of a pool of residential mortgage loans. Payments of principal, interest and prepayments are "passed through" to investors each month.

The Bloomberg U.S. Aggregate Index (BBG US Agg TR Value) is composed of approximately 8,000 publicly traded bonds including U.S. government, mortgage-backed, corporate and Yankee bonds. The index is weighted by the market value of the bonds included in the index.

The Bloomberg U.S. Universal Index (BBG US Universal TR Value) represents the union of the U.S. Aggregate Index, U.S. Corporate High-Yield, Investment Grade 144A Index, Eurodollar Index,

U.S. Emerging Markets Index, and the non-ERISA eligible portion of the CMBS Index. The index covers USD denominated, taxable bonds that are rated either investment-grade or below investment-grade.

“Bloomberg®” and the Bloomberg index(es) mentioned in this piece are service marks of Bloomberg Finance L.P. and its affiliates, including Bloomberg Index Services Limited (“BISL”), the administrator of the index (collectively, “Bloomberg”) and have been licensed for use for certain purposes by Thornburg Investment Management. Bloomberg is not affiliated with Thornburg, and Bloomberg does not approve, endorse, review, or recommend Thornburg. Bloomberg does not guarantee the timeliness, accurateness, or completeness of any data or information relating to Thornburg.

The performance of any index is not indicative of the performance of any particular investment. Unless otherwise noted, index returns reflect the reinvestment of income dividends and capital

gains, if any, but do not reflect fees, brokerage commissions or other expenses of investing. Investors may not make direct investments into any index.

Not FDIC Insured. May lose value. No bank guarantee.

Before investing, carefully consider the Fund’s investment goals, risks, charges and expenses. For a prospectus or summary prospectus containing this and other information, contact your financial advisor or visit thornburg.com. Read them carefully before investing.

Active by Design

Thornburg is a privately owned, global investment firm delivering active, high- conviction portfolios to institutions, advisors, and investors. Founded in 1982, we specialize in income and global equity strategies—each designed to support long- term goals and deliver alpha—available through institutional strategies, mutual funds, ETFs, closed-end funds, managed accounts, CITs, and UCITS.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: KCE: Capital Markets Shine As Financials Lag
data.description:
The Financials sector has badly underperformed the S&P 500 over the past six months. The Financials Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLF) is up just 7.8%, dividends included. Contrast that with the S&P 500 ETF’s (SPY) 24.7% advance. A stronger showing within Financials is Capital Markets. The SPDR S&P Capital Markets ETF (KCE) tallies a 19% return.

I had a "Buy" rating on the fund in May. I reiterate a "Buy" rating today. The valuation remains compelling, while the technical situation shows support appearing not too far away from the current share price.

KCE Beating XLF, Performing Close To The S&P 500

According to the issuer, KCE "seeks to provide investment results that, before fees and expenses, correspond generally to the total return performance of the S&P Capital Markets Select Industry Index." KCE provides exposure to the capital markets segment of the S&P Total Market Index. As for its construction and holding method, the fund employs a "modified equal-weighted approach, which provides the potential for unconcentrated industry exposure across large, mid, and small-cap stocks."

KCE remains a somewhat small ETF, with just $605 million in assets under management. That’s up rather notably from $435 million at the time of my previous analysis. Its annual expense ratio is low to moderate at 35 basis points, while the trailing 12-month dividend yield is not too far above that of the S&P 500 at 1.50% as of Oct. 29, 2025.

Share-price momentum has eased from earlier in the year, currently earning a B ETF Grade in that category by Seeking Alpha’s quantitative scoring system. KCE is a risky product, however, given its concentration in a single, often cyclical industry.

Finally, on liquidity, there has been some improvement since my Q2 assessment—average daily volume is now 34,000 shares, while the median 30-day bid/ask spread is slightly tighter at 16 basis points, per SSGA Funds.

For an update on the portfolio, the 4-star, Neutral-rated ETF by Morningstar has mixed exposure across the style box, though the majority of the allocation is found in the small-cap space, which adds to its cyclical and macro risk. Just 22% of the fund is classified as large caps, while there is a slight lean toward the growth style over value.

On valuation, KCE still looks compelling in my view. The price-to-earnings ratio is now 16.2x. While that’s above the 14.8x multiple from early May, it still appears favorable compared to the long-term earnings growth rate of 13.2%.

KCE: Portfolio & Factor Profiles

As for the sector breakdown, KCE is, of course, almost exclusively Financials. That’s a macro-sensitive sector, so trends in interest rates and overall Wall Street dealmaking matter greatly.

The modified-equal-weight portfolio means that no single position will command an outsized position in the product. So, earnings season should be less volatile with this ETF compared to other, more top-heavy, funds.

KCE: Holdings & Dividend Information

Seasonally, we are in the throes of a very bullish stretch. Historically, over the past 10 years of price data, KCE has rallied in October and November. November is, in fact, the best of the 12 months on the look back. December and January returns have been more muted.

KCE: Bullish Trends Through November

The Technical Take

With a favorable valuation and bullish seasonals, the technical situation appears conducive to further YTD gains. Notice in the chart below that shares are approaching critical support levels. First, the long-term 200-day moving average is on the rise, suggesting that the bulls control the primary trend. Additionally, the 200dma is just a few percentage points below the current level. Second, there’s a downside gap in the high $130s that would mark a key technical buying spot.

But take a look at the RSI momentum oscillator at the top of the graph. It has been trending lower since July. Note that the RSI peaked well before the price made a high (as is commonly the case). Today, the RSI has made a higher low compared to the mid-October trough. Still, the bulls have their work cut out for them, given a significant amount of volume by price up to the $158 resistance spot.

KCE: Key Support In Play, Possible RSI Improvement, Rising 200dma

The Bottom Line

I have a "Buy" rating on KCE. I see the Capital Markets industry ETF within the Financials sector as still solid on valuation, while the technicals point to limited downside risk as we progress through a bullish calendar stretch.

data.title: Musk's Pay Vote And BofA's Rare Investor Day Headline Busy Shareholder Event Stretch
data.description:
It seems like ages ago now, with Mag 7 names posting Q3 profit numbers today and tomorrow, but the big banks clocked in a clean sweep of bottom line beats two weeks ago. That sets the foundation for what’s turning out to be one of the strongest quarterly reporting periods in years. What’s more, S&P 500 consensus EPS estimates for the next 12 months are closing in on $300 for the first time.1

The SPX’s ascent to 6800+ yields a P/E ratio just below 23x. In short, both price and profits are in rally mode, which the bulls are happy to see. Meanwhile, volatility across the stock and bond markets has cooled after a mid-October scare that saw the Cboe Volatility Index (VIX) spike near 29. It’s back in the mid-teens now, just as the ICE BofA MOVE Index of Treasury volatility sputters close to 47-month lows.

The bond market gets its time in the spotlight today, Fed Day, of course. Yields have eased since May, thanks in part to gradually softening economic uncertainty. The macro backdrop is not pristine, but stocks seem to be pricing in a Goldilocks scenario. Big tech, big banks, and the man with the biggest net worth are in focus this week, not from an earnings perspective but from several potentially revealing shareholder events.

November 4-5: Lam Research and KLA, Two Semiconductor Bellwethers, Take the Stage

Chips are in focus on Tuesday and Wednesday next week. The days may be getting darker (for those of us in the Northern Hemisphere), but times have seemingly never been brighter within semiconductors. Both Lam Research (LRCX) and KLA Corporation (KLAC) are in the VanEck Semiconductor ETF (SMH). The fund has more than doubled off its April low, and all eyes will soon be on NVIDIA’s (NVDA) fiscal Q3 2026 earnings report due out on Wednesday, November 19.

Before that, Lam (virtually) hosts its Annual Meeting of Stockholders next Tuesday. There, shareholders could hear about new capital allocation decisions, which is particularly interesting right now given the heavy investment in AI and semiconductor manufacturing. Lam reported its fiscal Q1 numbers a week ago, beating on both the top and bottom lines. Projecting resilient revenue for the year ahead (despite sagging demand out of China), it’s reasonable to expect an upbeat shareholder event.

As for KLA, it reports tonight (October 29), after a slew of sell-side upgrades across the semiconductor equipment industry. Shares are higher by almost 100% on the year, and any additional clues on its order backlog or developments in China could move the stock. All the commentary sets the table for NVIDIA’s show later in the month.

November 5: Bank of America’s First Investor Day Since 2011

Perhaps the most consequential corporate event hits next Wednesday, when Bank of America (BAC) hosts its first Investor Day in 14 years.2 The long hiatus makes this gathering particularly noteworthy. The banking industry has undergone massive changes since 2011, from the implementation of Dodd-Frank amid the zero interest rate policy era to the digital banking revolution. Today, with crypto making institutional inroads and Treasury yields dropping from multi-decade highs, there are mixed signals for the big money center banks.

CEO Brian Moynihan will presumably grab the mic and offer details on BofA’s plans to navigate the new era. He usually keeps an upbeat tone, unlike his counterpart at JPMorgan Chase (JPM). Recall that Jamie Dimon talked of cockroaches lurking behind banking walls earlier in October.

BofA shareholders may seek fresh clues on the health of the consumer, along with how the housing market may evolve with the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dipping ever closer to a 5-handle. Furthermore, any added color on deposit trends, delinquency rates, or spending behavior will feed directly into how markets assess the health of the economy heading into 2026.

The Financials sector as a whole has been sagging on an absolute and relative basis. The group was leading for much of 2024 and into the first half of this year. An optimistic tone would nicely buttress BofA’s big earnings beat two weeks ago.

November 6: Tesla Shareholders Have Their Say

If BofA’s Investor Day is the C-SPAN of key corporate events in early November, Tesla’s (TSLA) shareholder meeting is like Entertainment Tonight. The list of key agenda items will be long, but surely the most anticipated is the vote on Elon Musk’s enormous proposed pay package.

The company’s board asks equityholders to approve a performance-based compensation award for the world’s richest person. It also stresses that if the package is not approved, the EV automaker - with its valuation pinned to robotics and AI - risks losing Musk’s “time, energy, and considerable talents.”3

It’s estimated that if the ambitious milestones are met, the package could net Musk a staggering $1 trillion in equity. That would require a TSLA market cap of a seemingly out-of-reach $8.5 trillion, along with other operational and strategic targets.4 If it’s not given a thumbs-up, Musk could retaliate or make other threats as the firm’s clear leader.

The shareholder meeting transcends Tesla and Musk, though. It could be viewed as a litmus test on corporate governance. It remains to be seen how aligned the board is with Musk, how independent it is, and how shareholder-friendly the incentives are.

The Bottom Line

Q3 earnings data and corporate commentary will be huge in the next few weeks, but investors should also keep close tabs on developments from virtual and in-person shareholder meetings and Investor/Analyst Days. Facts and figures regarding AI, the global banking environment, and perhaps even the future of corporate governance are financial wildcards in the week ahead.

1 FactSet Earnings Insight, John Butters, October 24, 2025
2 Bank of America chief Brian Moynihan shakes up leadership team, Financial Times, Akila Quinio, September 12, 2025
3 The Future of Tesla Is in Your Hands, Tesla, October 28, 2025
4 Why Tesla just threw $1 trillion at Elon Musk, CNN, Chris Isidore, September 7, 2025

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: VGIT: Intermediate Risk Duration
data.description:
Introduction

If you want to index your bond portfolio to interest rate variation, then the Vanguard Intermediate-Term Treasury Index Fund ETF Shares (VGIT) interests you. The ETF, owned by Vanguard, invests in US government bonds denominated in dollars, with intermediate maturities of between 3 and 7 years usually, with an expense ratio of 0.03%. This means that in this vehicle everything revolves around the movement of the yields of the treasury and the coupons that pay those bonds. In this case there are no corporate credit or mortgage instruments, which makes it easier for the reader to understand the investment universe described. Although the fund performs well overall, I believe that the conditions necessary for an optimal purchase are not in place, as the reader will appreciate in this article.

The operation of the fund is quite simple in this case. The fund collects the coupons on the bonds it holds and passes them on in the form of regular distributions to its investors. At the same time, the NAV rises or falls depending on what the Treasury IRRs do. In case they fall, the bonds are worth more and the ETF price rises; if the IRRs rise instead, the price falls. To all this must be added the roll-down effect of each bond, which is that as the bonds of the fund are maturing and managers renew them, if they do not change because the rate curve does not change, they are usually renewed at a somewhat lower IRR. This small decrease in IRR usually generates a discrete profitability bonus.

The sensitivity of the fund to rate movements is at a balanced point, as it has an average duration, depending on the type of bonds in which it invests. This allows the management team to manage duration risk in a more controlled way, in a more manageable way than if it were a long-term treasury fund. In a context of disinflation or less restrictive monetary policy as the current one, the 3-7 year tranche reacts well, as the price of the fund is able to pick up the understanding of returns and consequently will benefit a potential portfolio, including this type of vehicle.

To make this happen in an orderly fashion, Vanguard replicates an intermediate-duration Treasuries benchmark. The objective is to equalize the behavior of the index, discounting commissions, with a low tracking error. In this case, the monitoring operation combines two approaches. When liquidity allows, virtually everything in the index is bought at very close weights, resulting in complete replication. In case it is not worth having each CUSIP, the optimized sampling technique is used: which consists of buying a basket of bonds with the same characteristics as the basket of the index.

In the screenshot above, readers can see the different ETF data relevant to making the right decisions. Of particular note is the turnover figure of 52%. Although it is categorised as a D, this is not a bad figure. In an index ETF such as this one, bonds age and fall below three years, at which point they are removed from the index. At that time, the fund must sell them and buy longer issues to maintain the target duration. This simple ‘turnover’ generates structural rotation and justifies the turnover ratio.

Analysis - Macro Fundamental

In this section, we will analyze some macroeconomic indicators in detail to try to offer the reader an accurate perspective and a sound recommendation on the vehicle in question.

The first proposed metric shows three variables that are important for the analysis of a vehicle of this type. These variables are the shape of the rate curve (spread of the 10-year vs. the 3M tranche), the state of financial conditions as measured by the Chicago Federal Reserve (NFCI), and the liquidity boost, as measured by the 13-week change in the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet. As we can see in the graph, when the curve is reversed more, the market usually discounts situations of economic slowdown or rate cuts in the near future, which pushes down the IRRs of the 3-7 year stretch, which is where the analyzed vehicle moves.

If we add to this that the financial conditions are tense (NFCI), the classic “flight to quality” can appear, a situation in which the demand for treasuries increases. The third element we have, and include, is the Fed’s balance sheet. This variable gives us context in the aspect of the activity carried out by central banks. In QE situations, when central banks extract duration from the market through their asset purchase programs (bonds), they provide liquidity that often favors the maturity bracket of this type.

The signal is now at a neutral level, because the curve has undone some of the investment that it made a few quarters ago, the financial indicator (NFCI) does not indicate a severe tightening of conditions, and the Federal Reserve’s 13-week momentum is not being expansionary, at the moment.

With this situation in hand, we can say that, according to this first panel, the profitability of the ETF analyzed depends now more on carry and roll-down, than on a theoretical “macro rally” (decrease in real rates, more inverted curve, or increases in net financial liquidity).

In the second metric, we look at the main driver of performance for an ETF such as the one analyzed. We care mainly about the real cost of money and the inflation that discounts the market. As we can see in the graph, we have the green line, which expresses the inverted z-score of the real 5-year type. When this line goes down, future flows are discounted at a lower cost, favoring the nominal bonds of the 3-7 year tranche, which is where the analyzed ETF operates, as they increase its price.

The second key element to comment on here is the 5-year breakeven line (T5YIE), which is the variable that approximates the inflation expected by the market over that time horizon (5 years). In case this breakeven cools down, the inflation premium demanded by the investor drops, and, again, nominal IRRs tend to fall; for consistency, we also treat it as inverted.

The current reality is that the variables in the graph are in a neutral zone. This means that real rates are not at the local highs of a few months ago (this reduces downward pressure on the fund price), the breakeven variable does not show inflationary stress overflowing, and the “claims” element does not reflect a sharp deterioration in employment today.

Features and Performance Analysis

In the screenshot above, we show a comparison of the performance of the VGIT ETF, as well as its main characteristics (costs, AUM, and management), compared to two other ETFs in the same category, belonging to BlackRock (IEF) and Vanguard (BIV). As readers can see, the ETF analyzed outperforms its main competitor (IEF - BlackRock) in the long term. When analyzing why this is the case, we find the answer by focusing on the fees charged by each fund. The two funds managed by Vanguard charge an annual management fee of 0.03%, while BlackRock's ETF charges 0.15%. This difference is significant for us when choosing one vehicle over another.

As for the BIV ETF, it currently outperforms both VGIT and IEF. This is because it has the longest effective duration of the three ETFs compared. BIV currently has an effective duration of 7.2 years, compared to 5.6 (VGIT) and 6.9 (IEF). This means that within the intermediate tranche, BIV invests in maturities that are slightly higher than the other two ETFs, which gives it that extra return (it is also conditioned by greater exposure to corporate credit).

Conclusion

With this in mind, it makes sense to me to keep the vehicle in the portfolio. Readers may choose to let the monthly coupon continue to work, allowing the roll-down to accumulate and monitoring the thresholds of the variables discussed here. I recommend buying, but only if and when we see a potential catalyst for an increase in carry. Until then, stay out if you are not already in. Thank you for reading.

data.title: TransMedics: Q3 Results Disappointed, As Expected (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
TransMedics (TMDX) shares were down 9% in pre-market hours after reporting third-quarter results that slightly missed consensus revenue and failed to meet investors' high expectations.

The third quarter of the year is typically the weakest quarter for TransMedics, given seasonality. I also warned in August, ahead of earnings, that industry data isn't looking supportive.

With the stock down and Q4 shaping up strongly, I argue the setup is again favorable, which leads me to upgrade the stock to a "Buy."

Background

In my August article, I argued that industry data points to a weak third quarter for TransMedics, with a seasonal decline sharper than last year. At first, it seemed to me that the stock reflected that outlook, and so did consensus estimates.

However, after CEO Waleed bought a non-meaningful amount of shares (relative to his existing stake), shares jumped almost automatically, and that has led me to become more cautious.

To me, TransMedics came into the quarter almost as vulnerable as it was the last time around, with the stock more than doubling year-to-date and with elevated expectations.

For now, it seems my short-term assessment was correct.

TransMedics Q3 Results Once Again Catch Investors Off-Guard

TransMedics is a hyper-growth company that only really went commercial in late 2022. As such, Wall Street is still learning the stock, the business, and the seasonal swings. These third-quarter results seem to once again catch investors off guard, evidenced by the sharp response in the stock.

Revenue in the quarter was $144 million, up 32.2% Y/Y and down 8.6% Q/Q. Product revenue grew 33.1% Y/Y, and dropped 8.8% Q/Q, with OUS revenues (still very small) growing faster. Service revenues grew 30.9%, and dropped 8.4% Q/Q.

Gross margins in the quarter were up 290 bps on a Y/Y basis, but down 280 bps sequentially, given lower fixed-cost leverage. It's noteworthy that this is far better than the 470 bps we saw last year. Operating margin was 16.2%, significantly better than last year, but down 700 bps sequentially.

Looking ahead, they raised the low end of the 2025 guidance from $585 million to $595 million, now seeing $600 million at the midpoint. This reflects a Q4 that's in line with Q2 in terms of revenues, which would mean 8% Q/Q growth, and 27% Y/Y. That said, I think they are likely to come ahead of it.

Honestly, I don't want to pat myself on the back here, but the quarter turned exactly like I thought. Results were very much in line with expectations and industry data, but the shares' run-up ahead of earnings showed me that investors are unaware of what's to come.

Industry Data Points To Strong Q4

While the revenue pattern is still evolving, I think that our industry data analysis is providing an edge. It worked in the previous quarters, and in Q3, so let's hope it will work again.

What we are seeing is that so far, Q4 is shaping up much stronger than Q3. In Q3, we saw liver dropping 7.6% on a Q/Q basis and growing 5.3% Y/Y, heart down 2.8% and 2.2%, respectively, and lung down 8.4% and up 1.5%, respectively.

For Q4, we are seeing acceleration across the board. Liver is up 4.5% Q/Q and 14.5% Y/Y. Heart is up 6.7% Q/Q and flat Y/Y, and lung is up 11.0% Q/Q and 14.4% Y/Y.

As most of you probably know, liver is the most important segment for the company, so I expect to see strong results and acceleration in Q4.

Valuation

At the pre-market price of $122 per share, TransMedics trades at 52 times forward earnings and 42 times next year's estimates (though estimates will likely go up after the earnings beat). On revenue, TMDX is at 7.5x for 2025 and 6.3x for 2026.

As you can see on the graph above, the pre-market multiples are close to the low end of TransMedics' valuation range post-commercialization. In my mind, these are once again reasonable valuation levels relative to TransMedics' growth prospects.

More importantly, in this case, they also reflect undemanding expectations and beatable estimates, which are emerging as the key drivers for the stock, especially for near-term considerations.

I estimate the company's fair value at $160 per share, based on a 40x multiple on 2027 estimates.

Conclusion

TransMedics delivered third-quarter results that failed to meet the high bar investors had coming into the quarter, which is what I expected.

With the stock selling off, I see valuation as far more attractive, and expectations as beatable. Also, industry data points to a strong Q4.

As such, I now upgrade TransMedics to "Buy" and suggest exploiting the weakness.

data.title: Fed's Powell Raises Doubts About Another Rate Cut
data.description:
As expected, the Federal Reserve on Wednesday cut its target rate cut by ¼ point to a 4.0%-to-4.25% range. The drop marks the second rate cut this year, following the drop in the policy rate in September. A third cut by 2025’s close, however, is less likely, according to Fed Chairman Powell.

“There were strongly differing views about how to proceed [at the next policy meeting] in December,” Powell said during a news conference following the Fed’s rate-cut announcement. “A further reduction in the policy rate at the December meeting is not a foregone conclusion. Far from it.”

The bond market quickly took the hint and sold off, driving yields higher. The policy-sensitive 2-year rate, for example, shot up on Wednesday to 3.60%, a three-week high.

Fed funds futures are still pricing in moderately high odds that favor another rate cut at the Dec. 10 meeting, but the implied probability is 72%, which leaves room for debate about how the end of the year unfolds.

Part of the reasoning for possibly pausing on rate cuts is the delay in new economic reports due to the government shutdown. “What do you do if you’re driving the fog? You slow down,” Powell said, referring to the postponed numbers, such as the monthly payrolls report for September which remains in hiatus.

The lack of new economic numbers is “very concerning,” former Bureau of Labor Statistics commissioner Erica Groshen told Fortune, noting that the Fed is “flying blind.” She explained: “If policymakers build systems around data that can vanish overnight, that’s a real vulnerability for economic governance.”

The special release of consumer inflation data for September showed headline CPI rising 3.0% year-over-year, the highest since January. But Powell expressed a degree of optimism that to the extent that pricing pressure is rising due to tariffs, it will be a one-time effect that won’t push up inflation much longer beyond what’s already been seen.

“Inflation away from tariffs is actually not so far from our 2% goal,” Powell said. He advised that central bankers are looking for signs that tariffs only lead to one-time price increases for certain consumer products.

Despite the uncertainty linked to delayed data, weakness in hiring will likely keep the Fed on a rate-cutting path, predicts Jeffrey Roach, chief economist for LPL Financial. “The downside risks within the job market will likely ensure the Fed will continue to cut rates in December and throughout the next year,” he reasoned in a press release sent to CapitalSpectator.com.

The critical variable in the days and weeks ahead is how the Treasury market reacts. Was Wednesday’s rise in yields a one-off event? Or will the bond ghouls push yields higher and put more pressure on the Fed to forgo rate cuts?

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Peabody Energy: A Constructive Q3 And Further Improvements Ahead (Downgrade)
data.description:
Overview

Peabody Energy Corporation (BTU) is a U.S.-listed and domiciled coal mining company. It is the largest coal mining company in the U.S. based on production volume. With that said, it has over the last few years been getting the majority of its earnings and cash flow from the two seaborne segments, where most of the mines are in Australia.

In the last few quarters, the Powder River Basin and Other U.S. Thermal segments have had a larger contribution to the consolidated earnings for the company. This is due to softer seaborne coal prices, increasing electricity prices in the U.S., and a potential policy shift with regards to coal from the new U.S. administration.

Peabody is a company I have covered frequently over the last couple of years and my prior articles can be found here. This article will focus on the Q3 2025 results that was released this morning and the company is at 10 am CT today hosting a conference call, which can be joined here.

My most recent articles on Peabody have had Strong Buy ratings following an extreme selloff in conjunction with the Anglo American (OTCQX:AAUKF) coal deal, that led to balance sheet concerns by the market for Peabody. The stock price of Peabody has rallied a lot from the lows earlier this year, partly because this deal was cancelled due to a material adverse change.

Following the strong rally from its lows, I have lowered my rating from a Strong Buy to a Buy, as the risk reward isn't as attractive at this level compared to the sub $20 that we saw during much of this year.

With that said, I still think Peabody is an attractive investment and it is far from expensive, with what I think mid-cycle earnings will be for the company. The U.S. thermal coal now looks to be adding very welcomed optionality, where that optionality and a depressed valuation going into the year, explains the outperformance in 2025. Peabody is up 31% year-to-date, which is impressive when we consider that the drawdown this year was as much as 50% in April.

Q3 2025 Result

Peabody reported an adjusted EBITDA of $100M in the most recent quarter and earnings per diluted share were $-0.58. Adjusted EBITDA was slightly better than expected and up 7% compared to Q2. Earnings per share were below expectation, but net income was impacted by $54M in costs related to the terminated acquisition. Overall, this was a relatively positive result even if it was still a weak quarter on a historical comparison.

The Seaborne Metallurgical segment did see a rebound from the previous quarter when the EBITDA was negative in the segment. The sales price of $121/t was up 6% quarter-over-quarter, while costs of $108/t declined as much as 9% in Q3 compared to Q2. The EBITDA in the segment was a reasonably healthy $28M in Q3.

The Centurion mine will start longwall mining in Q1 2026, which is expected to have lower cost, and the sales price will demand a premium for its low vol coking coal. So, this segment is likely to start generating a more substantial EBITDA in the not-too-distant future, even if the seaborne coking coal market remains somewhat subdued.

The Seaborne Thermal segment saw a rebound in coal sales to 4.1 million tons in Q3, the sales price in the quarter was $59.3/t, an 11% increase compared to Q2, and the EBITDA margin was $13/t in Q3. The segment EBITDA was $41M, which is a decent amount given that coal prices have remained lower lately.

The Powder River Basin sold 22.6 million tons in Q3, which was a 13% increase compared to Q2. The realized sales price was slightly lower at $13.36/t, but costs declined even more, which led to an expanding EBITDA margin of $2.29/t. This is now the second quarter in the row when the segment has had the largest contribution to consolidated EBITDA of $52M in Q3.

The Other U.S. Thermal segment saw a higher sales volume, but the margin was just slightly positive in the most recent quarter, and the overall impact on consolidated earnings was consequently low.

The development project Centurion remains on track and on budget, it is expected to start longwall mining in February of 2026. Most of the capital is spent at this point and Peabody has $603M in cash and over $950M in total liquidity. So, there are no balance sheet or liquidity concerns for Peabody.

The company continues to pay a quarterly dividend of $0.075, which equates to a dividend yield of 1.1%, using the latest share price. Peabody has also been buying back its shares aggressively over the last few years, even if that has slowed lately. Once Centurion is fully ramped up and once coal prices start to normalize, my expectation is that the buybacks will ramp up again.

Conclusion

We are currently going through a weak period for coal prices, which relates to both thermal coal and metallurgical coal, even if we look to be off the lows earlier this year. Peabody has managed to weather this period relatively well due to its good balance sheet, diversified production, and different sales regions.

When looking at the historical or forward-looking EV to EBITDA, Peabody doesn't look all that cheap, with ratios in the 5-7 range. However, that is due to the very soft coal prices at the moment.

I would argue the mid-cycle EBITDA is probably closer to $1.5B for Peabody and the enterprise value is $3.0B, which takes the EV to EBITDA to 2.0. Let's say I am overly aggressive here, and the mid-cycle EBITDA is only $1B, which Peabody was able to double during the peak in 2022, and that was without Centurion I might add. Then the EV to EBITDA would be around 3.0, which isn't particularly expensive either. The attractive valuation is primarily why I continue to rate Peabody as a Buy, and it is a core holding in my portfolio.

There will always be risks to consider as well, where the commodity price risk is the main risk to be aware of as coal prices are cyclical. While I do think coal prices need to recover from the current level, coal prices can likely stay depressed longer than most expect. The good balance sheet, liquidity, and diversified production will offset the impact some for Peabody.

Another potential risk is litigation risk following the termination of the Anglo American coal deal, where Anglo American does not agree with the material adverse change following the ignition event at one of the mines. While I do think Peabody is likely to beat this in court, there is the possibility that the courts would side with Anglo American and force Peabody to pay a substantial break-up fee.

Overall, I continue to think that the risk reward is relatively attractive for Peabody here, even if we might see some more consolidation in the near term following the strong rally over the last 6 months. Centurion will provide a very welcomed boost to earnings next year.

data.title: Armstrong World Industries: Solid Growth Momentum And Upgraded Guidance (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Investment action

I had a hold rating for Armstrong World Industries (AWI) previously, as I thought the valuation was too expensive—so much so that there is very little room for error. My view has changed. While the valuation multiple is still high, I now believe multiples could continue staying at this level given the growth momentum, upgraded guidance, and tangible catalysts.

Q3 earnings

AWI reported a strong Q3 that really changed my mind on the business and outlook. Total net sales grew 10% y/y to $425.2 million, setting a new third-quarter high. The Mineral Fiber [MF] segment saw 6.2% y/y growth, driving sales to $274 million. While most of the growth came from favorable pricing and mix ($14 million contribution), volume contributed too, which was positive as this marks the second consecutive quarter of positive volume growth. And this does signal that the demand backdrop is recovering. As for the Architectural Specialties [AS] segment, it remained as the core growth driver, with net sales up 17.6% y/y to $151.2 million. To be fair, ~$16 million came from the 3form and Zahner acquisitions, but even if we adjust for these, organic sales still grew $7 million, or 6% y/y, and this is despite tougher comps. Margins were the only negative takeaway here. Consolidated adj. EBITDA margin contracted 120 bps to 34.7%, with both MF and AS seeing margin contraction. Anyway, I don’t think much attention should be paid to this margin pressure since the real takeaway is the 13.3% y/y EPS growth to $2.05.

Growth Accelerates, Justifying the Premium

When I last covered AWI, my hold rating was driven almost entirely by valuation. The stock looked expensive, and I wasn’t convinced there was enough room for upside surprise. After seeing the 3Q25 results and, more importantly, the upgraded outlook, I believe I have been too conservative previously. It seems clearer to me that the AWI growth story is actually getting much better, which justifies its premium multiple.

The key update here, I think, is management’s decision to raise FY2025 adj. EPS guidance. The new guide calls for a range of $7.45–$7.55, which implies 18%–20% y/y growth. Management also effectively dismissed the bear case (poor volume demand) for the MF segment by calling the market stabilizing and raising the FY2025 volume outlook. Remember that Q3 ended on 30th September, and the results came out just yesterday, which means management already had one full month of data (for Q4). This makes the volume guide credible.

Aside from the guide, AWI’s digital strategy continues to show its worth. I said before that this is a competitive edge, and AWI proved me right this quarter. The new highlight this quarter is Kanopi, an e-commerce platform that saw record sales and EBITDA. This is noteworthy because it confirms AWI’s ability to reach smaller and previously underserved customers profitably. The keyword is profitably, because anyone can chase after volume by heavily subsidizing it, but doing it profitably means that AWI has built a platform that can efficiently handle these smaller customers’ orders (low-volume orders, so it is hard to make the unit economics work vs. a large-volume order, as fixed cost is spread over a smaller base). From a growth perspective, this means AWI's growth runway has extended longer, as it can now go after the long tail of demand (e.g., demand from smaller contractors that typically require more niche products). Or you can just think of this as AWI expanding its total addressable market.

Meanwhile, the ProjectWorks design platform continues to gain traction as I expected. For recap, my general view was that ProjectWorks simplifies complex designs and installations, and that makes the life of architects easier, which drives adoption. However, it seems like I am missing a part of the story. Management noted another benefit that I thought was very bullish. This ProjectWorks design platform doesn’t just make the life of architects easier; it also addresses the problem of labor shortages in construction. By automating design rules and stepping up the pace of iterations, ProjectWorks actually increases productivity for contractors as well. Rather than directly reducing the number of labor contractors needed, it drives efficiency by reducing “wasted attempts.” Better design rules and iterations result in precise bills of materials that reduce the frequency of rework.

Another potential growth catalyst is the office segment, which represents ~30% of AWI’s total demand. Most readers would know that the office segment has been a drag on the business ever since Covid (more work-from-home policy that reduces the need for office spaces). However, we may have reached an inflection point. For the first time in seven years, US office vacancy rates have moved lower (per a third-party data cited by management during the call). This is too early to call it a recovery trend, but it does support the narrative of the ongoing return-to-office trend. AWI is already seeing early benefits, with increasing tenant improvement projects in its order flow. Tenants wouldn’t spend capex to improve if they are not seeing improving end demand. In my view, this could be a meaningful swing factor. Even if the office market simply stabilizes, it removes an overhang on the stock, and in the bull case, if it becomes a tailwind, it could unlock incremental volume and operating leverage.

Balance sheet and capital allocation

On the balance sheet, I don’t see much of a problem for AWI to continue reinvesting for growth. The business is generating a good amount of cash (adj. free cash flow is up 22% year-to-date), allowing it to fund growth without tapping hard into leverage. In fact, the business is generating so much cash that in Q3 alone, management raised its dividend by 10%, repurchased $27 million of stock, and even did a bolt-on acquisition (bought Geometrik for $7.5 million). I am not incorporating this into my base case, but there is a potential for AWI to re-lever up its balance sheet back to the historical leverage ratio (>1x EBITDA) and return that cash to shareholders.

Valuation

My view on the stock has changed for the better. I think there is a good chance that AWI will continue to grow as low-teens (FY25 13% was guided), and if we keep margins flat, earnings could grow to $470 million in FY28, and that solid growth (relatively better than peers, as shown below) should continue to justify multiples to stay at the current premium elevated level (23x forward PE vs. peers with an average of 12x). While I noted that the last time this happened, the multiples re-rated downwards quickly, I think this time may be different. There are visible growth catalysts that could continue to support growth. Also note that the recovery in the office segment could elevate growth higher.

Risk

There are execution risks that could hurt growth. Specifically, the AS segment growth still depends on successfully integrating 3form and Zahner, which are currently weighing on segment margins. If the synergies are lower than expected, earnings growth could be weaker than I expected. On costs, about $6 million in Q3 operating expenses were one-off expenses that management called out as timing-related, and we should see a sequential improvement in cost. The risk here is that ongoing inflation, especially in energy prices, could mask this “improvement,” and the market may inch closer to being conservative when modelling margins (I am modelling flat; they may model declining margins).

Conclusion

I am upgrading my rating on AWI to buy. My previous view that valuation was too high is no longer the case given the growth momentum and raised guidance. The digital strategy also continues to work, with Kanopi and ProjectWorks showing tangible results. There is also the office space segment that is finally showing signs of inflecting into a tailwind. All in all, I can bridge to a nice upside case if AWI can continue to grow at low teens with a 20% net margin.

data.title: Alphabet: Growth, Buybacks, Cheap P/E
data.description:
Alphabet (GOOG) reported better-than-expected earnings for its third fiscal quarter on Wednesday amid strong, double-digit growth in its core Search and Cloud businesses. While Search advertising contributed nicely to the company’s top line growth in Q3, the real story for Google is the expansion of its operating income in its Cloud segment which is driven by accelerating AI product adoption.

Google previously said that it was boosting its capital spending in a bid to accelerate the growth in its AI and Cloud businesses, and the tech enterprise raised its CapEx guidance again. With demand for AI products increasing, I remain optimistic that Google is in a strong position to grow its earnings and free cash flow going forward. Google's shares are the second-cheapest, after Meta Platforms (META), in the big tech industry group and have revaluation upside, in my opinion.

Previous rating

I rated shares of Alphabet as a strong buy -- Chrome Ruling Is A Game Changer -- due to the tech platform recently receiving a favorable Chrome ruling that allowed Google to keep its important and highly profitable web browser business. Further, Cloud is showing material growth momentum, both in terms of revenue and operating income, and since shares are still cheap, I confirm my strong buy rating for Google following the Q3'25 report.

Google beat Q3’25 estimates by large margins

The tech enterprise beat consensus estimates on both the top and bottom line for the September quarter: it reported normalized earnings of $3.09 per-share which out-matched the consensus EPS estimate by $0.83. The top line came in at $102.4B, out-matching the average prediction by $2.2B amid a strong Cloud and digital advertising performance.

Strong Cloud operating income growth

The main story for Google, now and in the future, will be Google Cloud which benefits from growing demand for AI products in a market that is funneling hundres of billions of dollars annually into the Data Center market. As more workloads shift to the Cloud and companies are willing to spend more money on AI products and services in order to grow their businesses, realize cost efficiencies and improve productivity, Google’s Cloud Platform is in a robust position to make growing operating income contributions to the company’s financial results.

In Q3'25, Google generated $102.3B in revenue, showing 16% year-over-year growth. Google Search, which represents 55% of consolidated revenue in Q3, benefited from a strong digital advertising market: here, Alphabet generated 15% year-over-year revenue growth and achieved a total of $56.6B in revenues. The firm's total operating income reached $31.2B, showing 10% year-over-year growth.

Cloud is where all the action is for Google, despite the segment being only 27% the size of Alphabet's Search business (based off of Q3'25 revenue contributions). Google Cloud generated $15.2B in revenue, showing 34% year-over-year growth and the segment saw a significant operating margin upswing compared to the year-earlier period as well: Cloud generated $3.6B in total operating income (+85% Y/Y) which calculates to an operating income margin of 23.7% (+6.6 PP Y/Y). The Cloud segment's operating income is therefore growing ~8.9X faster than its consolidated operating income.

In the third fiscal quarter, Google remained widely profitable, which is mainly due to the earnings consistency in the Search business. The tech enterprise generated free cash flow in the amount of $24.5B in Q3'25, showing 38.7% year-over-year growth, meaning the company's free cash flow grew more than twice as fast at the company's revenues. Google achieved a free cash flow margin of 23.9% in the third-quarter, showing a margin expansion of 3.9 PP compared to the year-earlier period.

$millions Q3'24 Q4'24 Q1'25 Q2'25 Q3'25 Y/Y Growth
Revenues $88,268 $96,469 $90,234 $96,428 $102,346 15.9%
Net cash provided by operating activities $30,698 $39,113 $36,150 $27,747 $48,414 57.7%
Less: purchases of property and equipment ($13,061) ($14,276) ($17,197) ($22,446) ($23,953) 83.4%
Free cash flow $17,637 $24,837 $18,953 $5,301 $24,461 38.7%
Free cash flow margin 20.0% 25.7% 21.0% 5.5% 23.9% 19.6%

Source: Author

These numbers highlight a very well-performing core business -- Search and Cloud -- and with operating income and free cash flows surging, Google is in a great position to return more cash to investors in the future.

In the third-quarter, the tech platform spent $11.5B on stock buybacks and $40.2B year-to-date. And more stock buybacks are likely to get executed in Q4... which should especially benefit the Search business given the inclusion of the holiday period. Going forward, I expect Google to invest more money into:

  1. The development of new AI-driven products, such as AI queries, which are integrated into Search and Cloud and which accelerate Google's growth in the core business
  2. Data Centers in order to accommodate soaring demand for AI-driven workloads. In this regard, Google just raised its FY 2025 CapEx outlook from $85.0B to a new range of $91-93B and the company has guided for a significant CapEx boost next year.
  3. Stock buybacks. The tech company may boost its stock authorization next year and potentially increase its buyback size (from a current $70B authorization) if free cash flow performance remain strong
  4. The acquisition of AI start-ups. In order to accelerate its AI-centric growth strategy in Search and Cloud, Google may turn to a more acquisition-focused approach to boosting its top line growth.

Google’s valuation

In the past, I recommended Alphabet chiefly because the company was the cheapest big tech stock, despite delivering double-digit top line growth and being highly profitable. Shares of Alphabet are currently trading at a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 25.7X, but are still relatively cheap compared to other big tech companies in the industry group... many of whom trade a significantly higher earnings multipliers.

As revaluation catalysts for Google I see 1) Accelerating AI spending in the enterprise market which could drive results in Cloud especially, 2) Expanding operating income profitability, driven by AI product up-take in Cloud, and 3) Strength in digital advertising spending backing up the firm’s largest segment (Search), especially in the fourth-quarter... which is typically a strong one for companies selling digital ads.

In my opinion, shares of Alphabet could revalue to a ~30X P/E ratio fairly easily... under the condition that Alphabet continues to grow at double-digit rates and CapEx spending in the enterprise market doesn’t slow. Google is currently expected to generate $10.73 per-share in earnings in FY 2026, implying 8% Y/Y growth, which calculates to a fair value of $322 per-share.

Risks with Google

The biggest risk for Alphabet, as I see it, relates to a potential slowdown in AI-driven CapEx spending in the enterprise market which could hurt the company’s growth momentum in the Cloud business. What would therefore potentially negatively impact my bullish view on the technology firm is if the firm's stellar Cloud-driven growth moderated or if Google saw a deterioration of its free cash flow margins.

The firm's strong FCF is key to Google's AI-driven CapEx ramp as well as stock buybacks, so any deterioration in the fundamentals of the core digital advertising market is likely going to have a severe valuation impact on Google's stock outlook.

Final thoughts

Google has received a steady stream of positive results in the last several months including a favorable court ruling regarding its Chrome browser which pushed shares into a new up-leg.... and now the company has submitted an earnings scorecard that crushed Wall Street's estimates.

Google is well-positioned as one of the largest public Cloud platforms to cash in on AI-driven Cloud growth and the company is seeing impressive operating income growth. Google's strong Q3 earnings report highlighted robust growth momentum in both Search and Cloud and strength in free cash flows... which is likely going to add to investors' already positive sentiment about the company. After the earnings report, shares of Google soared 7% in the after-hours market, but I see more room for shares to appreciate.
